If she'll use her inhaler,
Her breathing won't fail her.
And, smoking must stop, if you please!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Bacteriuria (germs in your pee)
Means your kidneys or bladder may be
Attacked by a germ
(Not a virus or worm).
Take some medicine ASAP.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
A state of division's "diffission".
Deficient, is this definition?
Despite your derision,
This here's my decision:
Sufficient.  Here endeth my mission.

limerick_list.author: AronKuppersmith
limerick_list.text:
If you write algebraic notation,
Use the infix style for the equation.
Using Polish, you know,
Is much less apropos
To describe the expression's relation.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I thought things were going so well
Till she vanished completely.  She fell
Off the face of the earth.
I received a wide berth.
I don't know where she went.  Hope it's Hell.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I met Mary, was lovesick, then scared,
And I might have cried out if I'd dared.
Though my heart ached inside, it
Seemed best that I hide it—
For chest pain I wasn't prepared.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
On Good Friday, the Tenebrae light
Is snuffed out, flame by flame.  Shadows fight
The one light that holds vigil
Till Christ bursts the sigil,
For Easter detenebrates night.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
There are so many finches I've seen;
There's the rose- and the gold- and the green-.
They're small seed-eating birds
And too pretty for words.
Of their species I've counted umpteen.

limerick_list.author: Harris Risman
limerick_list.text:
In the end you'll seek quaint little byways,
But to get there, controlled access highways
Are the routes that you'll take.
(Those are facts that aren't fake;
They are real and not pie-in-the-skyways.)

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
We sell LGBTs first-class clothes.
For the gays, we boost GaySox fine hose.
I am pleased to report
They give legs great support —
Just like gaysocs. Their following grows.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
What you have is no keloid, fibroma,
Benign swollen gland, or lipoma.
The cause I confirm
Is the Epstein-Barr germ.
Your condition is Burkitt's lymphoma.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
When at Clontarf brave Brian Boru
Beat his foes though his numbers were few,
He was slain in his tent
By retreaters then bent
On revenge for the Vikings he slew.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
He was caught selling pills to a narc
Just outside of the school, in the park.
Seems his past had been checkered,
And now on his record
He's added another black mark.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
He looks like he sleeps in a flop
And he brags of his conquests non-stop.
On the web, he was sweet,
But it's clear once you meet
That this guy doesn't deal from the top.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
Our shrinks have examined your pad
And the swastikas drawn there, my lad.
Those daggers you doodle
Say inside your noodle
You're probably stark raving mad.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
If you want one, supply your own priest.
Bring a brown paper bag in, at least.
That's to hold the cremains —
The burnt body and brains
Of your dearly belovèd deceased.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
You gratuitously blame me for stuff
That goes pear-shaped. It isn't enough
That it's wholly unjust
And uncalled for, you thrust
Random insults at me off the cuff.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Harmonious music is poky,
Compared to a polka that's hokey.
Accordantly, braying
Accordion playing
Accompanies bad karaoke.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Nick's a drug pusher. Often he finds
That this pitch works on kids of all kinds:
"From the past, break the chains!
Have some fun with your brains!
You have nothing to lose but your minds!"

limerick_list.author: old dad
limerick_list.text:
The speaker is dull, on too long.
A tense restlessness runs through the throng.
A comfort break, brief,
We all need for relief —
Oh my God, he's just burst into song!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Many buttresses slope on the top,
Then run up to a building and stop.
Architectural geeks
(All amortizement freaks)
Talk of piers with their peers at the shop.

limerick_list.author: Mr E S
limerick_list.text:
We drank wine, a divine Spanish red,
And on pheasant most pleasant we fed,
'Til I bit on a pellet
Of birdshot.  Oh hell, it
Has crushed my bicuspid with lead!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Copulation's my lifelong obsession,
So sleep's but a squandered digression.
In the words of my ex,
"God knows you love sex."
(If God knows, then I'm skipping confession.)

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A bonnet could sit on your head,
Skirt a sail, or trap fishies instead.
It could perch on a lorry—
A whole 'nuther story—
Or turn grass into milk in a shed.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Your fervent belief in the Rapture
Has, sadly for everyone, sapped your
Desire to care
About what's in the air:
All the carbon we now need to capture.

limerick_list.author: Dixon Wragg
limerick_list.text:
An amorous fellow named Benton
Propositioned a young girl from Trenton.
She said, "Never, you cad.
All my love is for Dad!"
(Daddy's now getting his in San Quentin.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Dad said, "Bad money drives out the good,"
But this concept I'd not understood.
He explained, "Coins of gold
Are the ones you would hold.
Those of plastic you'd spend if you could."

limerick_list.author: bestswanbird
limerick_list.text:
Here's some commonplace, vegetable lore:
See this lovely big cabbage? Ignore
All the leaves and the roots
And the little green shoots.
Take the pith; that's the castock, the core.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
On my first day at Copenhagen U.,
Anne IM'ed me from out of the blue.
With computers our major,
Her text was, I'd wager,
A coincidence, truly: "DIKU?"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When Prince Charles married Princess Diana,
We sang: "Hallelujah! Hosanna!"
But the marriage broke down.
For the heir to the crown
Ms. Camilla was still top banana.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
You edits my righting so good,
Like a reel copy editor would.
But you looks so perplext,
Copyediting text,
When my Egnlish gets miss understud.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
City Beautiful's social reforms
Made safe housing and hygiene the norms.
The goal of this movement
Was moral improvement
Among burgeoning working class swarms.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Deltiologists, one might suspect,
Study deltoids, but that's incorrect.
They are hobbyists who
Buy and trade and accrue.
Picture postcards are what they collect.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Carbon fibre is lightweight and strong,
Made from graphite, by drawing out long
And thin filaments, heated
And otherwise treated,
Then woven. It's tough as King Kong.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
My dog, though he's quick, ain't a greyhound,
And he's not, without training, a stay hound,
But he thinks that his job
Is to fetch what I lob,
Which, of course, makes him ace as a play hound.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
Some canines are trained to attack
(Of empathy they have a lack),
But I'm trained to lick
And write limericks slick—
I don't even dare to talk back.

limerick_list.author: Son of Baltimore
limerick_list.text:
Where current must flow is a factor,
When planning to use a contactor.
So if you don't know
Your N.C. from N.O.
Then it's best that you call a contractor.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A woman who fancies she can
Wangle all that she needs from a man
Will remain in his debt
For each gift she will get—
Not to mention each pot and each pan.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle and J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
Biological parents are free—
If they wish—to beget and then flee.
Caring people who opt
Both to seek and adopt
Others' children are heroes to me.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
Abhominal beasts are unkind,
Inhuman, and hardly refined.
Lacking tenderness, crude,
They're barbaric and rude
And to savage behavior inclined.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Among carpets, this carpet's a queen,
Even though it is made by machine.
Loops of wool sewn on linen
(Its strong underpinnin')
Make it great—Brussels carpet, I mean.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Surely even the fair Cinderella
Had the nasi that's named columella.
That's the small fleshy band
That 'tween nostrils will stand,
Issued one to each lady and fella.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
The best bovine waitress we'd seen
Was Bess at the old Dairy Queen.
To thank her for dipping
Our treats, we tried tipping,
But tipping a cow's kinda mean.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Man's all-powerful? Give me a break!
Such pretension's not easy to take.
He cannot bring to term
One diminutive worm,
And yet gods by the dozen he'll make.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
A hard-throwing pitcher is Lee,
Whose fastball is real hard to see.
On this toss to the plate,
I unloaded too late,
And the ump pumped his fist with, "Strike three!"

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Enceladus, scientists say,
Has a sea, we were told just today.
From the lecturer's notes:
"Saturn's moon got most votes
As Most Likely for Life." Hip-hooray!

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
There's some woman who looks kinda jumpy,
And a hairy old man growing grumpy.
Is the cause his moustache,
Or a short fall in cash,
Or the fact that his lap dancer's frumpy?

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Dick expressly desired (in particular)
To indulge in some extracurricular
Functions at school
With the girls, as a rule
Not performed in a pose perpendicular.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
In a memory firm and unfaded,
I remember Bo Derek's hair, braided
Into cornrows, so tight.
Didn't like it?  You might
Be upbraided for being so jaded.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
As a healer, the bland obstetrician
Had little financial ambition.
He loved ladies deeply,
So treated them cheaply —
Half-price if they caught his condition.

limerick_list.author: Edmund Conti
limerick_list.text:
At the goal line—so close—coffin corner!
The punted ball's out and the mourner,
The returner, aghast,
Stands alone (the die's cast!)
With his thumb up his ass like Jack Horner.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
Alas, that she's lamb-bedecked mutton,
Not young, and for loving, a glutton.
But she strolls through my bowers
Admiring these flowers:
I'll give her a bachelor's button.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Your new girlfriend's so thin! We must flatten out
The folds in her bra. Pat should fatten out,
But to stuff her with pie,
We must first get her high.
Ask the waiter to bring a Manhattan out.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
The Captain said, "Beam us up, Scotty—
I'm afraid and I want to go potty!
We've been trapped by a Klingon
Who hasn't a thing on,
And he seems to think Spock is a hottie."

limerick_list.author: otherwisefine
limerick_list.text:
When a footballer's caught with the ball
At his feet, and there's no time at all
To be turning about,
He might hope for a shout
And can back-heel it back to the call.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A bowyer's a guy who makes bows;
You can meet him at archery shows.
And you'll find he's the sort
That is thrilled by the sport—
He's aquiver from hairline to toes.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
"Teenage" cowbirds will face a sad plight
If they don't learn behavior that's right.
This is not done by day,
And we now know how they
Gain this knowhow — they sneak out at night.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle and Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Achritochromacy grieves
Every color-blind person who weaves
Through a garden's displays
But can only see grays,
So the flowers have hues like their leaves.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
We're a site with a lofty ambition.
The rule is that every submission
Needs humor and zing
Plus one vital thing:
A definiens (that's definition).

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
She is playing it safe; apprehension
Of heterosexual tension
Has this lady, though straight,
Seeking gay guys to date.
Call her fag hag (semantic invention).

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
Poor Penelope pondered the ways
Of how to present crudités;
She spent many hours
Sculpting vegetable flowers
Which her guests gobbled up without praise.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Please abbreviate Rosemary Phelps
To Rosie. She says that she guelps
Her half-cups of T,
Saving time — do U C?
(U don't have 2 B mad, but it helps.)

limerick_list.author: Type A
limerick_list.text:
Richard Nixon's is eight-ninety-five.
Gerald Ford's is worth less (he's alive).
I collect and I traffic
In things autographic.
"John Hancocks" I sell to survive.

limerick_list.author: Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
Afropop's not a cola Ebola,
Like a soda consumed in Angola.
It's pop music they play
In an African way.
It's heard worldwide. Now where's my payola?

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
The gourmet, blessed with taste unsurpassed,
Emerged from the diner aghast.
His look of revulsion
Came from the emulsion
Of grease dripping from his repast.

limerick_list.author: pkwooster
limerick_list.text:
His bank account's totally flush.
He got there ahead of the crush
Of miners who came
For fortune and fame.
He's known as the czar of the rush.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
A long parting again must be faced.
Hugging tightly, they fiercely embraced;
Every clasp in the past
Has proved fast love can last
When on friendship and loyalty based.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
My Irvine's  a tenor (and louse).
He does drugs and he drinks — what a souse,
But we weep and get chills
When his "Danny Boy" trills.
Ah, there's not a dry eye in the house.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
"What's an amphiphile?" "Ma, tell your daughter!
Any -phile isn't doin' what he oughter."
Ma said, "Pa, hold your peace.
Just means one end grabs grease,
While the other end dives into water."

limerick_list.author: AegNuddel
limerick_list.text:
A beer garden snack sure to please,
Often partnered with pretzels, one sees.
It's made in that area
Known as Bavaria—
Allgauer Emmentaler cheese!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Your noodle, I think you have rocks in.
This test tube is filled with a toxin
Called curarine—power
To kill, in an hour,
Six bulls, twenty calves, and two oxen.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Though the prices in stores may be steep,
"As ye sow," they say, "so shall ye reap."
It's no bargain if I
Go to jail when I buy
Out of somebody's trunk on the cheap.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
An illusory sense of wellbeing
Whose name (through assumptions agreeing
With states rather sweet)
Is fool's paradise—neat.
But sweet outcomes I'm not guaranteeing.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
The frame of this clamp forms a C;
Screw it closed—it resembles a D.
It holds tight when I glue
What I've broken in two.
It sure suits that ol' task to a T.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
Controversially! That's how they'll teach
Their beliefs on design. Can they reach
The public school masses
In all science classes?
If so, it's Creation they'll preach.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
The teenager titters and teases
With skirts to her knees, as she eases
Her feet into hose
Known as bobby socks—those
Reach her ankles; in winter, she freezes!

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
It envelops me, toe tips to head,
But my diving suit fills me with dread—
In the sea it springs leaks
(Mr. Verne of them speaks
In his book—twenty thousand, he said).

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
When I queried an ag statistician,
"Will my corn crop survive to fruition?"
"If you choose to peruse
And then use GDUs,
They will help you accomplish your mission."

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
Not all ladies are skinny, it's true;
Some are plumper, but that's nothing new.
When you cuddle and kiss
With a shapelier miss,
Call her butterball, pal, and you're through.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
You'd been missing for nigh on ten years,
And I'd long since accepted my fears.
Then a letter from you—
What a bolt from the blue!—
Was delivered; my eyes blurred with tears.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Go from Munich to Salzburg and take
There at Chiemsee a not-too-short break.
See the palace (French style,
Li'l Versailles) on an isle
In this greatest Bavarian lake.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
Find some words that mean "lazy" — my quest.
How is indolent? Slothful? This test
Is clearly invidious,
And since I'm desidious,
I can't finish this verse. I must rest.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A croustade is a shell or a puff
In which bakers put minces and stuff.
As for those filled with fruit?
Shoot, there ain't no dispute—
It's of these I just can't get enough!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Creatophagous, Ed's son likes meat.
"It's nutritious, and all that I eat."
He declares, "When I've dined
With my sister, I find
Eating carrots I feel like a cheat."

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
The insurer's reaction pugnacious
Doomed my car, once so stylish and spacious,
To be destined for scrap;
And I'm meant for the trap
Laid by stingy adjusters predacious.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
There's a star called "the back of the Bear"
Which is almost the brightest one there.
Dubhe's typical role
Is to point at the pole;
It's a cinch, 'cause it's part of a pair.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
He's a biggie in Baghdad, and few in
Iraq are complainin' or booin'.
If folks had to name
Just one hero, I'd claim
That Muntadhar al-Zeidi's a shoe-in.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Said the soon-to-be-married Marie,
"I'm a damned, oh-so-sad bride-to-be.
I must wed old Henri
And die young, of ennui.
I shall no longer be fancy-free!"

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Robert Blake (the detective Baretta)
In real life became quite upset—a
Defendant on trial
For the venting of bile
Through his gun, in a lover's vendetta.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
The Marines can't take Bush anymore
And they'd like to show Cheney the door.
While they stay Semper Fi,
The executives lie.
They're both rotten, say I, to the corps.

limerick_list.author: VERaLOE
limerick_list.text:
Dominican: order (or state
Which is small, not exactly first-rate
There in Hispaniola);
Whereas Savonarola,
The Blackfriar, simply was  great.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
Your music's not personal, Miss!
From your earphones I'm hearing a hiss,
And I feel persecution
From noisy pollution!
Tss-tss, tss-tss-tss, tss-tss-tss.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
It is easy to spot evil twins
By the hair that they grow on their chins.
They're goateed, so you should
Know they're up to no good.
Little beards are the signs of their sins.

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
But Portia (that doctor renowned)
Ruled that mercy, unstrained, could be found
In the bond, for no flood
Of that life-fluid, blood,
Was, along with the flesh, fully bound.

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
If a bovine in some leafy glade
Should swallow a live hand-grenade
Then surely it's vile
(Though the word makes me smile);
It's abominable — that's what he's made.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
The Cydippida zips at a clip;
Its combed cilia ship with a flip.
This round jelly's equipped with
A belly that's tipped with
Two tentacles: whip, grip and nip.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
"Do not play with those cards!" Mom would scold 'em.
"Those card games are evil!" she told 'em.
But her kids still would play
Hoping maybe some day
They could make lots of dough playing Hold 'em.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I'm aware of the hazards I face
In this unsecured perilous place.
I'm exposed here alone
In a known danger zone.
I need help or I'll sink without trace.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
My abstinent girlfriend, Enola,
Loves whiskey and Price Chopper cola.
We drink until one
And have riotous fun
Watching reruns of Charlie and Lola.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
A rivulet, also called ghyll,
To a poet might offer a thrill,
While the wooded ravine
(Also ghyll) where I've been,
Is a place where I like to sit still.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
My brother's a pest.  Shoulda slugged
The dumb schmuck when he constantly tugged
On my arm, asking, "Bro,
Where'd my book of maps go?"
But, not seeing his atlas, I shrugged.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
In the sixties, we sought to declare
Our disdain for conventional hair;
And pursuing our hippiness
With typical dippiness,
Eschewed the mundane and the square.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The bowknot's embellishing loops
Are arrayed in a couple of groups
To the left and the right
Of a knot that is tight.
If it's loose, you could trip and go "Whoops!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
In a move that is sure to amuse,
Saint Lou's Church of Perpetual Booze
And Wild Parties permits
Beachside services. It's
A discalceate order (no shoes).

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
The styles of Bret Harte and the Queen,
In the English tongue—know what I mean?—
May appear on a par;
But for me it's bizarre
To be writing betwixt and between.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
"If you wanted to churn, then make butter!"
I yell at my broker, who'll utter
Excuses for churning
My stocks, which are turning
So much, my account's in the gutter.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
In old Concord, New England, they wrote:
Now they're viewed as great writers of note.
And though Thoreau was jailed,
Peace and concord prevailed,
Near the bridge of that hymn which we quote.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
"Alright," he insisted, "let's start.
Now, those who despise it, take heart:
We're taking this word,
Alright, as you've heard,
And tearing it all right apart."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
We attended our son's graduations
At five different college locations.
We'd prepared for success
Every time, as you'd guess.
Yes, we always had great expectations.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This compound is diabetogenic.
There's no diet and no calisthenic
That will ward off these ills.
If you swallow these pills,
Then no more will your life be irenic.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Charlie Chan, Chuck E. Cheese, Charo too!
All challenge my choppers to chew
On their chattering names
While I'm chanting their fames.
Throw in old Chubby Checker; I'm through!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
She's attached to her youngest son Paul,
And it's driving her friends up the wall.
That he's seven but still
At her breast makes them ill.
What's she say? "Hey, you can't wean 'em all!"

limerick_list.author: Ibid
limerick_list.text:
I'm so sad your whole life is a mess.
Dog died? Let me share your distress.
Neither lover nor hater,
I'm a trained consolator.
Pay in cash, or I couldn't care less.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
First some aliens kidnapped our cow,
Then our son ran away with our sow.
The way our luck runs,
Twenty vultures with guns
Should arrive here along about now.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
To accommodate suffixes may
Be appended to aid what you say.
Adding -ness means "the state
Of felicity," mate.
Adding  -ly? "In a suitable way."

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Though its rhymes and its meter are lawful,
People think that this limerick's awful
'Cuz there's nothing to cause 'em
To think that it's awesome
And e-mail their friends that they're ROFL.

limerick_list.author: josephmcg
limerick_list.text:
The almanac writer collates
A reference of data and dates:
Of the phase of the moon,
Or the rainfall in June,
Or the general whims of the Fates.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
A great country-lover am I;
The green fields, the brown earth, the blue sky.
When tramping the hills
I am far from all ills,
Then home to my bed by and by.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My momma's high hopes, expectations:
I'll receive many sports acclamations.
I've one medal—to wit—
For the distance I've spit.
I said, "Mom, it's for great expectorations!"

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Here's a meaning on which I have pounced:
It's "a judgement that's formally pronounced",
"Condemnation", "a sentence".
Your lack of repentance
Means punishment: doom leaves you trounced.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
See these curvative leaves, students, please?
Slightly undulate margins have these.
Now class, no one denies
That to leaves that applies;
And the same could be said of Louise.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A cupuliform cataract? Wow!
That must trouble your vision, 'cause now
Your posterior capsule—
Though there may be some gaps—'ll
Make everything cloudy—and how!

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
Call Alfredo an eyetie or wop,
And he'll angrily tell you to stop.
But then call him dago?
He'll hit you, or may go
And talk to his mafia pop.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In the words of antique anamneses,
This fish is a poisonous species.
I speak of the cackerel,
Which, unlike the mackerel,
When chased, tends to spew out its feces.

limerick_list.author: Reia Light
limerick_list.text:
I bought flowers, and ironed my clothes
For my date with that cutie named Rose.
But wait! I've a breakout!
Now how will I make out,
With hideous blobs on my nose?

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
On the train I at last found my proof:
In our carriage, a section of roof
(Having windows and vents)
That is raised represents ...
Yes, a clearstory, if I'm no goof.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The OEDILF, that omnificent versery,
For talent provides a great nursery.
We grow and we thrive
And come May of '05
We will have us our first anniversary.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My approach has earned words of reproach
From Bob Boacher, our bowling team coach:
"The approach is the place
You haphazardly race
Left and right: the approach of a roach."

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
His Tierleben (Animals' Life)
Taught the world about animals' strife
And their habits as such,
In six volumes. (That much!)
Alfred Brehm's grasp of creatures was rife.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Thanksgiving, the constable said,
Is a day that the cops always dread,
When these folks far and wide'll
All turn avicidal,
And bodies keep showing up dead.

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
Wrap the sari with care, moving slowly.
Then the free end drapes over the choli—
That's the blouse that you wear—
So your midriff is bare,
Whether willowy or roly-poly.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
The collodion process, "wet plate",
Leaves my bank account looking just great.
Given negatives, more
Of what butlers once saw
I run off at a lucrative rate.

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
If the ducks in your pond make you ill,
You will doubtless need many a pill
That's prescribed by some quack
At ten dollars a crack,
And then you'll have to (web)foot the bill.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Attoparsec, the word that I bring,
Is a measuring sort of a thing.
Astronomical base
But you take a mere trace:
Just an inch is the distance to swing.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
I refudiate only to teach
Academics beyond my own reach.
Like Shakespeare I tweak
The words that I speak
To dissemble intelligent speech.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
Adrift in the waves on the beach
Was a beachball  I couldn't quite reach.
Each time that I tried,
A wave swept me aside
And my toddler let out a sharp screech.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
The prison guard's phone call struck fear:
"Send me constables quickly, you hear?
There are getaway gangs
And I think I heard bangs.
I'll be called Billy-no-mates, it's clear."

limerick_list.author: hugh t.
limerick_list.text:
There's a moist exudation that's welling
From trees (genus Prunus excelling);
It's called cherry-tree gum.
(Guess who might have used some
For mending the tree he'd been felling?)

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
Your deceivableness means that you're thick,
And you'll gullibly fall for a trick.
A person who's less
Than respectful might guess
You're a hick or a yellow-haired chick.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
To depolish means take off the shine
From an object or something that's fine:
Make a slick surface worse,
Or degrade a good verse
To make too many syllables in a line.

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
Most congressmen just aren't good savers;
To bills, they add earmarks: plain favors
That have nothing to do
With the laws they're tied to.
They're just pork (of political flavors).

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
If a process or program's effective,
It fulfills an intended objective.
But alas, with my plan,
Things have all hit the fan,
So I'll need to take actions corrective.

limerick_list.author: Steve Andersen
limerick_list.text:
The amalgamated union of trees
Stands united in facing the breeze,
But each year they learn
That the leaves always turn,
And collectively they're gonna freeze.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Enemata: enema's plural —
A meaning that I'm very sure'll
Not be a surprise
To those language-wise
Who played word games, vice sports intramural.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A card shark's not really a fish
That you'd catch, cook, and serve in a dish.
He plays cards with finesse,
Or he cheats, I would guess;
Either way, takes your pay (that's his wish).

limerick_list.author: johng
limerick_list.text:
To swim in the sea, if you're keen,
A wonderful sight may be seen.
It's a flag, coloured blue,
Which, from your point of view,
Means the beach has been deemed safe and  clean.

limerick_list.author: Steve Andersen
limerick_list.text:
Asbestos is awesome, we learn,
A most difficult product to burn.
You can cook it a lot
And it never gets hot,
But it's toxic, and something to spurn.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If a mustache you happen to view
Has long tendrils, it's possible you
Might recall that old joke
About "Many men smoke"
(That's tobacco) "but then Fu Manchu."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Choreographer Paula Abdul
Had the moves that made Lakers fans drool.
Now American Idol
And stardom worldwide'll
Confirm that she's nobody's fool.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Diogenes cynically slated:
"Some aspects of Homer seem dated."
This ancient Greek dawg meant
That, lacking an augment,
The aorist's tense is unstated.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Very gifted, frustrated, young Brian
Has the rage of a caged, captive lion.
But what often is missed
Is this man's velvet fist,
Which is caged in a glove made of iron.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Do I shuffle and frown? Au contraire!
I'm as footloose as Freddy Astaire.
I could aerobate, and
(If you don't understand)
I'm referring to walking on air.

limerick_list.author: David Bourke
limerick_list.text:
Arachnoid's an entry that tends
To confuse. What's it mean? That depends.
"Fibrous membrane" the Lord
Built 'round each spinal cord,
Or "resembling our eight-legged friends."

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
If your research design's differential,
You've certainly got the potential
To draw correlations,
Just not the causations.
Review Line 4 twice — it's essential.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas and Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
"I figger I'll do me some killin',"
Laughed Ross.  "I get off on blood spillin'."
With a razor his tool,
He was brutal and cruel,
Slashing dozens, this barbarous villain.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
You're defeated. Don't try to pretend
That you've anything left to defend.
These surrender terms need
To be signed, so proceed
To the dotted line, right at the end....................

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Brecciation's the breaking apart
Of a rock into fragments, the start
Of a new brecciation
Through sedimentation.
It'd break a geologist's heart!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Dad, today I begin my career
In a field that I know you hold dear.
It's garbage removal!"
He beamed his approval
While proudly suppressing a tear.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Our town's Christmas display, a large spruce
And three reindeer, draws kudos profuse.
I'm in charge of the four,
But I like the tree more.
I deduce that the spruce won't break loose.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Might she give me the big eye? I wish!"
I confessed to a friend. "Meg's a dish."
He conveyed what I'd said,
But then, badly misled,
Meg well-meaningly gave me a fish.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
He's the target of scorn and abuse,
And he's frequently told to vamoose.
He's the butt of the jokes
From us regular folks—
And he's putting his head in a noose.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Well, your gizmo is broke: it needs glue, dad.
The doohickey's out of date too, dad.
This thingumajig
Just don't fit (it's too big).
Whatcha want is a new god-darned doodad.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In his workshop, the artist Vermeer
Keeps a rod called an artist's bridge near,
And he rests his right hand
On this firm wooden band
So the paints on his canvas don't smear.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
That corrupt good-for-nothing Raul
Thinks that living on welfare is cool.
He says, "Why should I work
Every day like a jerk?
I get money for nuthin'," the tool.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Sweet Aragon! Province of Spain,
Where I hoped, with my love, to remain.
Zaragoza was wet.
I came home with my pet,
For the rain falls, in Spain, on the plain.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
She will let you write page after page
On her life on the screen and the stage.
But one thing you must guess,
For she'll never confess
To her true chronological age.

limerick_list.author: prionix
limerick_list.text:
The power to see words and read,
This disorder of brain does impede.
Should writing perplex ya,
You might have alexia,
Making useless both novel and screed.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Say, buddy — yeah, you — spare a match?
This here place? It's the old booby hatch.
And my penguin's all right,
But he don't have a light
To ignite this here nicotine patch.

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
Neolithics who ceased to exist
Were buried inside of a cist:
A pit lined with stone,
Where the dead lay alone
(Not a very nice place for a tryst).

limerick_list.author: jojo
limerick_list.text:
When the sergeant calls out "about face!"
He expects you to turn in your place
One-eighty degrees,
And he sure won't say "please."
So you'd better hop to it apace.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Dryopithecine ape? I'm agape.
It is small, but it's primate in shape.
Though it's no missing link,
It's important, I think—
This extinct little ancestor-ape.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Libs flame Donald for what he has written:
By emails and fake news he's bitten.
But I love him extremely
For tweetstorms unseemly;
The meaner he gets, the more smitten.

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
I feel comfortless — life's a bad dream,
And I just can't get up any steam.
I know I'm a jerk
Who can't find any work;
I no longer fit into the scheme.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A degree-day is not graduation,
But a measure of climate. This station
Submits daily forms.
Do we vary from norms?
If Earth warms, will we see variation?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
When you're rating a bottom, it's fine
For a ten to be top of the line.
But it's rather inane,
If not downright insane,
To be calling a bad asinine.

limerick_list.author: jexia
limerick_list.text:
Within seeds, there is life to be freed
If they have the conditions they need.
They will germinate (grow)
Leaves above, roots below,
Then mature to a bush, tree, or weed.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
Ankle surgery?  That's a real pain!
On our marriage it sure is a drain;
Doctors' visits are cued up,
His foot joint's all screwed up.
Playing nursemaid will drive me insane.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Piccadilly: unchained, what a sight!
An escritoire (as in "to scrite").
Inside: Ponk, all contorted.
Is Grytpype-Thynne thwarted?
On a raven and it, Poe did write.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It is true I enjoy eating food.
When I'm sad it can lighten my mood—
But the calorie count,
When I eat, tends to mount,
And my fears of foul fatness intrude.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The party, at best, was half-hearted,
So this friendly advice I imparted:
"Why is nobody drinking?
What the hell are you thinking?
Let's break out the booze and get started!"

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
It's one of those moments in time
That verges upon the sublime:
You are high on a hill,
All alone, and quite still…
Then the bells of a church start to chime.

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
It's quite clear, so there's no use denying
That you gamble with living and dying
When you boldly repeat
Every stunt, trick, or feat
That I'd duly dub darn death-defying.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Cimolite: soft, earthy clay
Full of minerals. Whitish or gray,
It was used to make pipes
For tobacco, the types
Ancient Indians thought were okay.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Dear America, home of the brave,
You must soon learn a new way to save.
Your 'AAA rated'
Has now been abated
To 'AA plus' status — that's grave!

limerick_list.author: Michael Daws
limerick_list.text:
With my oils, on the canvas I frolic,
Painting tableaux disturbed and symbolic.
Bedecking his horns
In stigmata and thorns,
My messiah's a touch diabolic.

limerick_list.author: rwt
limerick_list.text:
My computer makes limericks with flare,
Using syntax that's abstract and rare.
The verses are drafted
With clauses well-crafted
In FORTRAN with ELSEIFs to spare.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
What's incumbent on somebody trying
To get re-elected?  Denying!
Watch him moving his lips
As his policy flips:
The incumbent's decumbent.  (He's lying.)

limerick_list.author: monro
limerick_list.text:
Though wee Pedro was always quite sickly,
Acitrónes would perk him up quickly.
Just out of the sack,
He'd head for a snack:
Candied pads from a cactus that's prickly.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
The EiC's stricken with panic
By my limericks, written in manic
Magniloquent patois.
They're now banned, by a fatwah:
My verses, he says, are satanic.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I'm Christopher, true, but I ain't
Like that fella I'm named for—the saint.
I was sinless till twelve,
When I started to delve
Into matters that made my mom faint.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
We're all on the same hymnal page,
And singing our hearts out on stage.
It's in church, where we blend
Many voices and send
Music soaring, our souls to assuage.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
What Joe labels buzzards are not:
Those are vultures hunched over the spot
Where a skunk double-stinks
On the shoulder. (Joe thinks
I'm a pedant who doesn't know squat.)

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
Louisa May Alcott was brimmin'
With stories about Little Women.
When she wrote as A. Barnard,
Adult praise was garnered
For tales wild as unripe persimmon.

limerick_list.author: Rudi
limerick_list.text:
What the bartender did was a howler!
I have never been served something fouler!
I asked for some beer,
But my "b" wasn't clear,
So an ear's what I found in my growler.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Thanks for waiting; I'm nearly OK.
I awoke a bit dauncy today—
Somewhat under the weather.
But I'll pull it together,
And our journey can get underway.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Expertise at his craft became clear
As our carpenter capped his career,
Using exquisite grain
(Always hard to obtain)
And selections of choice crotch veneer.

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
When experts say wine is amusing,
It's a compliment.  Ain't that confusing?
Why laugh at a wine
If you think that it's fine?
Methinks they do far too much boozing.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
My cardiac rhythm's been read;
And it's slow, like an athlete's, they said.
Bradycardia's nifty—
My heart rate is 50.
(Any lower, you're practically dead.)

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
My neighbour's got two lively boys
Who freely make use of their toys.
Their juiciest plums
Are two large sets of drums,
Creating an ear-splitting noise.

limerick_list.author: Fleur De Lim
limerick_list.text:
Throat's all raw after bouts of much hacking;
Nose streaming, sore head feels like cracking—
I'm one frightful mess
In the depths of distress!
Hey, one good thing—this cold curbed my snacking!

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
The Akasha's a record for tallying
All the good things and all shilly-shallying.
I have lived many lives
With children and wives;
It's all written, with whom I've been pallying.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
I'm attempting to keep the tone civil,
But your argument's absolute drivel.
Its content is worthless
And message is mirthless.
Be seated on this, please, and swivel.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A biker who's careless, like Mike,
Is the kind transplant patients all like.
On his donorcycle, Michael
Could crash and his bike'll
Mean others may ride down the pike.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
When the formula's wrong for your glass
Then the alkalis often will pass
To the surface and cause
Minute crizzling; these flaws
Make your heirloom now worthless, alas.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Two fists meeting knuckle to knuckle,
The lads' fist bumps made all of us chuckle.
Every team did the same
At the end of each game—
Not a handshake or kiss that is buccal.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
"Now, Rabbi, you listen to me,"
Said the sultan to Shabbetai Zvi.
"Here's the choice you have got:
It's convert, or — garotte.
Ah, la-la, you're beginning to see!"

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
My decimal keeps on repeating
Its digits while meeting and greeting
Its smaller divisions
Of 1—those incisions
Keep shrinking but aren't self-defeating.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
There are folks in this Church, it appears,
For whom anagrams fall on deaf ears.
By reshuffling (I've heard)
All the letters, the word
Presbyterians makes Britney Spears.

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott and R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
If you deep link a page on this site,
From the home page you don't have to fight
Through an indirect route.
And for those who might doubt,
Go ahead and click here — am I right?

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
"I'm committed to Caesar.  All hail!"
Cried a Roman, too eager for bail;
But his loyalty left
Him no license for theft,
And he's just been committed to gaol.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
"In the desert the aridness dries
Out the skin and all else," she decries.
"There's no water out here,
Bring me lotions, my dear,
And some onions for wetting my eyes."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Employe: this word seems to me
So bizarre.  How'd this form come to be?
Finding workmen at ease,
Did Old Scratch say: "Puh-leez!
I will chop off their word's final e."?

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
Acromonogrammatic holds true —
Ending letters start lines that are new,
With each letter that starts
So the former line parts.
Say — it's not very easy to do.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Laurie Morse always works like a horse.
For our team, she's the prime driving force,
With her pep talks and nagging
When spirits are flagging.
We've made her our captain, of course.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
Belousov-Zhabotinsky reactions
Are compellingly striking distractions.
The swirling BZ
Reaction's set free
In an unstable mixing of fractions.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Say goodbye to the beef and brûlée!
I'm beginning my diet today.
Though I stand on this scale,
I'm not reading its tale,
'Cause I aim to be wasting a weigh.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Found some manuscripts, timeworn and rare,
At an auction on Christopher Square.
Bought just one; I can't buy ya
Another Messiah.
The package reads "Handel with care."

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
An electrical charge in a cell,
Created when one's muscles swell,
Is called  action current
(Though its voltages aren't
So high that they make people yell).

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
A biaryl has two aryl groups,
And the aryls have resonant loops.
Her motif goes beyond
What makes pharmacists fond,
For she'll conquer the rest when she stoops.

limerick_list.author: Wattlebird
limerick_list.text:
My first thought was, "I'm going to jail!"
(A court summons had come in the mail.)
Civic duty for me —
On a jury, we'll see.
Now I have to respond without fail.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Armfield yelled to his Negroes at dawn
(Each sad soul in his coffle a pawn,
Of all dignity shorn,
Some from family torn,
Cruelly chained), "Lazy niggers, move on!"

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
In the Bible, the writers were fibbing —
If not lying, then surely ad libbing.
What boob would believe:
"Take a rib, make an Eve?"
It is we who are taking the ribbing.

limerick_list.author: Lostock Hall
limerick_list.text:
When the Alles he thought he was Über
Closed in on one A. Schickelgrüber,
He said: "Sod the Big Three.
Argentina for me
In a U-Boat I've fitted with Scüba."

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
Having three weighted balls that are bound
By a cord made of leather, you've found
You're a boleadora,
And your purpose is for a
Quick bringing of cows to the ground.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Her piece was a brief causerie:
A few words on the Queen's Jubilee—
On the poems of praise
And those traffic delays—
All as English as afternoon tea.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
The magazines chosen by leaders
(Or wanna-be super-succeeders)
With paper that's coated
Are glossies, devoted
To tastes of sophisticate readers.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
Wow, I'm nervous! I twitch! I perspire!
And  my boss has just used the word fire!
If this job we don't land,
I'll be out packing sand
As our bid time drops down to the wire.

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
Ng svefg, jung V fnl vf pbaprnyrq:
Guvf pelcgbtenz npgf nf n fuvryq.
Ohg fvapr lbh unir oebxra
Gur pbqr, nf n gbxra,
Guvf yvzrevpx unf abj orra erirnyrq.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
An observer of chemiotaxis
Might wonder if cells display praxis.
Is it conscious intent
Makes them follow a scent,
Or mechanical anaphylaxis?

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
limerick_list.text:
The meaning of duncify's plain:
To empty the smarts from the brain,
To make dull or make dumb,
Or cause thought to go numb,
Which results in ideas quite inane.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
In the past the term country estate,
Often prefixed by royal or great,
Meant the seat of a gent
Supported by rent
From his tenanted lands. With me, mate?

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
The big chief at the top of the pile
Says what's what, takes control. If you rile
Him, beware—he can strike,
Do what you might not like.
"Big kahuna no talk about trial."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In this limerick I'm writing about
The top rank in the line—Eagle Scout:
Many Boy Scouts will try
For this level—it's high,
And it offers a great deal of clout.

limerick_list.author: Danny Cannon
limerick_list.text:
A portly old man, seeming nice,
Offered draft-dodgers help, for a price:
"So, you want to be flatfoot?
Choose this foot or that foot—
I'll hop on your arch once or twice."

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
I've given up chocolate for Lent.
Since Ash Wednesday, my days have been spent
Feeling moony and dreamy,
Remembering that creamy
Delight with its cocoa-rich scent.

limerick_list.author: Pie Snelson
limerick_list.text:
When Pa got his luggage in Reno,
He found he'd forgotten his Beano.
He lit up the joint,
But more to the point,
His win(d) emptied out the casino.

limerick_list.author: EdRush
limerick_list.text:
An electroscope measures a state
Of electrical charge (while you wait).
A voltmeter acts
Much the same, finding facts
On, say, dry cells you ought to update.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I had done what I once thought was best:
I enriched myself, feathered my nest,
While I left in the lurch
My whole flock and my church.
Now I'm wealthy, it's me I detest.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
You're the dynamo, go-getter type
Working hard to excel.  Here's my gripe:
I'm no lackey to you,
So don't ask me to do
Things like "Go get my slippers and pipe."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I said to my woman, "You're drooly."
She thought I had treated her cruelly
By calling her that.
"You want drool?"  Then she spat.
"It just means that you're sexy, dear—truly!"

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
For rambling I'm ambling inclined,
Not to roam leaving home far behind.
Neither tropic nor pole
Is my hot pick or goal—
I prefer to bestir in my mind.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
There's a finch with a mortified grin,
And he's red from his tail to his chin.
Much too late he has heard
Shacking up with a bird
Is considered a cardinal sin.

limerick_list.author: AronKuppersmith
limerick_list.text:
No more moveable type made of lead!
Desktop publishing's used now instead.
With a tablet or mouse,
You can bring down the house
With a layout that knocks 'em all dead.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Oh, the clown is a gruesome disgrace!
Red facepaint: his grin is in place;
Scarlet nose for disguise
And black crosses for eyes.
Give me cold cream: I'll wipe off his face!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This pitcher plant trap's entomophagous;
Insects slide down its leafy esophagus.
Yes, the plant is carnivorous,
In fact, insectivorous.
Be glad that it isn't androphagous.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Modern cordless devices are neat:
You control your TV from your seat,
Changing programme or tone,
While a new cordless phone
Lets you talk as you walk down the street.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
It's a Cantinflas mustache you chose?
Fairly rare, almost all the hair goes.
There isn't much to it.
It's easy to do it:
Just shave everything under your nose.

limerick_list.author: Derek Redfern and Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
If your grades keep on stalling at school,
And you haven't the drive to be cool,
You're an aimless, ambitionless
Drifter — transmissionless,
Shiftless, and parked without fuel.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
He was typical TV news fare:
Perfect teeth, perfect clothes, perfect hair.
But the things that he said?
He's a damn barking head!
He's aggressive, abusive, unfair.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Wally's wanted in west Colorado;
He plunders with wanton bravado.
When he shoots, he don't miss.
If we ever catch this
Desperado, let's use the strappado.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
All the animals prisoned in zoos—
Are they there 'cause they're paying their dues?
Will they wind up, still penned,
To then meet a sad end?
Up to me, it is not what I'd choose.

limerick_list.author: Ulfras
limerick_list.text:
I was plagued by a terrible itch
That was making me fidget and twitch.
But my scratching created
An itch aggravated;
Turns out Mom was right, the old witch.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
As you hear, it's a part of the word;
Lure's a trick both for you or a bird.
When the baited poised trap
Has ensnared the prey (snap!),
To escape is quite hard, have you heard?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A boiler may well be unsound
If corrosional grooving is found.
Is this wearing away
Far too much? I can't say,
But I noticed that steamfitter frowned.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Jimmy lives off the state. What a slob!
He rejects any work; hear his gob
Spew the line: "No enjoyment
From this 'ere employment!
So  I fear I'm not up to the job."

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
We're surrounded—it's time to give in.
Ammo? None. Let's start saving our skin.
Course of action to take?
On the end of this stake
Tie a cloth—white, of course—yell, "You win!"

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Cohobation: the distillate's tossed
Back onto the dregs. At what cost?
Lots of charcoal, I'd say.
It's an alchemist's way
To concentrate what has been lost.

limerick_list.author: FunkyTuba
limerick_list.text:
Muscle fibers have A-bands. Explained:
They are darker than I-bands when stained.
Their look also changes
As view angle ranges.
Like hair bands, they tear when they're sprained.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
No weapon did we stow away
In a cavity.  Searching today,
They probed nostrils, mouths, ears,
Genitalia, and rears.
We could then catch our flight to L.A.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
I'm a chilled-out and indolent fellow,
So aftergrass makes me feel mellow.
It's the grass that is grown
When the first lot's been mown—
And I watch it dry up and turn yellow!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Brazilwood's a tree, and it grows
In Brazil, where the Amazon flows.
Once it's cut, if you're willin',
Extract its brazilin;
And its wood makes fine violin bows.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
In a baby, physicians agree
That abdominal defects can be
Where some organs may fall
Or protrude through the wall;
An exomphalos there we will see.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I'll embosom my child; I'll enclose
And I'll shelter him—save him from foes.
While I foster and cherish
The boy, he won't perish.
I'll nurture my son while he grows.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
In the data center, safe from attack,
Sits a dedicated server, in black.
It unceasingly runs
Keeping zeros and ones
Just for me. Call it Jeeves-on-a-rack.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
When you thrust with your trusty épée,
Your opponent may turn it away.
If you happen to tarry,
He'll follow his parry
With counterthrust, point, and "Touché!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I don't know but what Archie's a phony.
I met him last summer at Coney.
He promised me marriage—
I hate to disparage—
But what Archie had said was baloney.

limerick_list.author: Carol O
limerick_list.text:
A Highlander living in style
Liked socks knit in patterns argyle.
For this diamond-based plaid
He would simply go mad,
Leaving solids and stripes in a pile.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
One fs, femtosecond, is small;
It's so tiny, it's not long at all.
This truth I elicit:
Don't blink or you'll miss it
Since light barely moves at its call.

limerick_list.author: operadirector
limerick_list.text:
Born in Strasbourg, the artist named Arp
(With his first name there's reason to carp)
Gave us sculptures organic.
If you see one, don't panic —
Just say "Ah! Biomorphic!" (You're sharp.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
My wood looks so good on its outer:
Its edges and corners I router.
I don't care a damn for
A flat, bevelled chamfer;
I fillet (of angles, a flouter).

limerick_list.author: Brent Annable
limerick_list.text:
When I saw them, I swelled with emotion
And I swore my undying devotion
To these nymphs of the sea,
To these gill-bearing three—
The branchiferous maids of the ocean.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Every soldier should have it, ideally,
This boiled, hardened leather, cuir bouilli.
If we seal it up right,
It becomes water-tight,
And makes shields indestructibly steely.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
At the sLip, sipping ouzo with ease.
Non-stoP atmosphere, life is a breeze.
Here (of Kos) we have fun.
All Rhodes lead to the sun
In the Symi-lar Dodecanese.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The centerpiece sits on the table.
A flowered arrangement, it's able
To garner attention
And positive mention—
Till football begins on the cable.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
Aristae means bristles, like those
That adorn ears of corn, I suppose.
An arista's just one;
If you're graced with a ton
You're aristate.  With that we shall close.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
When I brushed up against him today,
Touching lightly while passing his way,
And I noticed him blush,
I was caught in a rush
Of excitement and feeling risqué.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Before him, a leader has three
Seder matzoth.  A half broken free
From the center one's hid,
And the one lucky kid
Who can find it?  A prize he will see.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
A golf ball mis-hit just last week
Has altered your looks. Your unique,
Lovely face I recall;
It's been marred by that ball —
Freckled forehead, pert nose, dimpled cheek.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
She goes hunting used pop cans all day:
Loads of empties she's stashing away.
She's been cramming her closets
With nickel deposits.
She'll redeem them. Well, some day, she may.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Black locust's the kind of a tree
That's familiar as coffee or tea—
Not a plague that would harrow
The Biblical pharaoh—
The tree whose first cousin's a pea.

limerick_list.author: Colin Salter
limerick_list.text:
Cacophonic, the music of Tallis!
Polyphonic excess, choral malice!
In his counterpoint, clarity
Yields to vulgarity.
Yet he's popular down at the palace.

limerick_list.author: Ritepath
limerick_list.text:
Global warming is coming, I hear!
Sound alarms! Change your ways! Quake with fear!
The world's getting too hot!
An alarmist? I'm not! —
That is just what they called Paul Revere!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Try this cheese made from buffalo's milk
(Not like cheddar or Swiss or that ilk) —
Barilotto (that's barrel
In Italian) — and there'll
Be one thing to say: "Smooth as silk!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It's beef, or it's pork—but not turkey—
This meat with the name that is quirky.
Just hand me your car key;
I'll shop for some charqui—
Come back with a pack of beef jerky.

limerick_list.author: Shelby Forrest
limerick_list.text:
A Canuck known as Sass, with his son,
Fished the river 'til daylight was done.
It was easy to see
That his son had caught three,
But no one saw Saskatchewan.

limerick_list.author: Screenhog
limerick_list.text:
With runners on first, second, third,
The thwack of the baseball was heard.
The fans stood and squealed
As it left center field.
The infrequent grand slam had occurred.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Let's consider a word and its twin,
And with exteroception begin.
Here reaction, no doubt,
Comes from something without,
Whereas interoception? Within.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Does a foot locker lock up your feet
So you can't walk around in the street?
No, it's just a small trunk
To contain all your junk
By your bed, within reach and discreet.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
A mind that expands helps you gain
The most from a life that is sane;
Though some intellects bright
Shine from skulls that are slight,
There are big-heads who use half a brain.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Berlin Wall falls: speak Gorbachev's name
If you're playing the liberal game.
Credit Reagan?  No way!
9/11: just say
It's not Clinton's fault — Bush is to blame.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
I took Dinah to dinner tonight—
Our first date. It got late. We got tight.
"Like a nightcap?" she said.
Did her eyes hint at bed?
Just one thought filled my head—Dinah might!

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
Are you having a bout of the blues?
Seeing life through miasmas of booze?
Don't give up, don't go felo-
de-se; find your halo!
Aura therapy's what you can use.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn and Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A priest, reading mass, wasn't blind;
Eyed a lass with a luscious behind.
Just under his alb, a cross
Hung like an albatross.
White was his robe, not his mind.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
When I'm scared, in a state of alarm,
Or perturbed, when I need to stay calm,
I take Ativan pills.
Though they manage such ills,
They're addictive; they could do me harm.

limerick_list.author: Jim Vincent
limerick_list.text:
Grain and sacrificed animals (male)
Used for offerings, blessings prevail,
And the glory of God
Shone before them abroad:
They fell frontwards, soon prostrate (and pale).

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Bungee jumping, post-lunch, I debate.
My stomach suggests that I wait.
"Go on, do it!" goads Nate.
With encouragement great,
I jump down but throw up what I ate.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
In conflicts or wars it's expected
Humane treatment will not be neglected.
Thus all states must appraise
How to act in the ways
The Geneva Conventions directed.

limerick_list.author: CruzerX
limerick_list.text:
See that chick in the Jag? What a witch!
There just ain't any bitchier bitch.
And she bitchily knows
That her bitchiness shows,
'Cause she just ran me into a ditch!

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
To play serious bridge you must know
All the rules and conventions, and go
To competitive games
Where everyone blames
Their partners when good hands they blow.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
List the reals from 0 to 1,
Then perform this diagonal run:
Change a digit in each
To construct (so they teach)
One more number that's real. You're done.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
An acquaintance is one, to my sorrow,
I might not acknowledge tomorrow.
He's not like a friend
To whom I would lend
But, conversely, from whom I might borrow.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
I thought we'd be taking it slow,
To whate'er destination we'd go.
But you're now in a rush,
Pulled the lever marked "flush",
And advised me to "go with the flow".

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The name of this tribe made me squeal; a
Quick toast I drank down in tequila.
Now I've sent them a plea, "Uh,
Can your name, the Cahuilla,
Be pronounced so it's rhyming with Sheila?"

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
What's a word for a strumpet or whore,
A courtesan, wench... (there are more)?
The answer, my friend,
Is blowen—I spend
So much time with the one who's next door.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
Your unspoken praise I surmise
When I see glowing pride in your eyes.
Words of praise, I esteem,
But the height of my dream
Is the praise that you cannot disguise.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Suburban development's fine.
As more buildings go up, cities shine.
Brick-and-mortars today,
Though, could soon be passé
If we all did our shopping online.

limerick_list.author: art bates
limerick_list.text:
A young skier who lived in Peru
Had a ski that detached from her shoe.
The face-first fall she took
Was sure one for the book—
And her backside was imprinted, too.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
It's heartbreak to read acridology
When the subject affects my psychology.
I'm helpless to stop
My mind's grasshopper hop
Onto anagrams — wow! — cardiology!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Our Bootlegger's gone," Frankie fumed,
"So our booze-lovers' luncheon is doomed!
Drinkers love to get at
Aged cheeses like that
Since with whiskey it's often consumed."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The soothsayer smiled, and then said
He could prophesy what lay ahead,
Relying alone
On his amphicome stone;
Then he asked me to join him in bed.

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
I note with sporadical glee,
The basidiomycetous tree
Of the fungi was thought
To be two-branched. What rot!
It is rusts, smuts, and mushrooms (that's three).

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Carol June, M.S., Janis, J.D.
Shared our summer commencement day glee:
Sisters, husbands, kids, Mom
Watched us strut with aplomb,
Sans regalia, sipping high tea.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
Near the toilet seat, hubby, you've seen it.
There's bacteria on it — I mean it.
Still, in bed you caress it,
And while eating you press it —
Your cellphone's so germy. Please clean it!

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
When it rains, little Barbara stays jolly
In the shade and the shield of her brolly.
She will splish-splosh and twirl
While umbrella spokes whirl,
Nearly taking out eyes in her folly.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
With bulk purchasing, here's your first clue:
Just buy basics, like kangaroo stew.
Once I happened to spy
A full lifetime supply,
And the price was so low I bought two.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Let's tell Sadie, "Go tend to the brute."
When she blushes, I find it real cute.
He's a "male-cow" to Sadie,
Who's ever the lady.
Her propriety's always a hoot.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
The leg of a pig prevents famine,
Cured and sliced into rashers of gammon,
Fried or grilled; then the sting
Of some mustard's the thing
(Or a pineapple ring) to examine.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
The constant that Boltzmann called k
Was this physicist's effort to say
"Let the energy pass
To each atom of gas
In a temperature-sensitive way."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The molding that runs round the hall
In our home, near the ceiling, we call
A cavetto, whose curve,
Being concave, will serve
To keep dust farther down on the wall.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The adermia term that we lack
Needs some writer to give it a whack.
I've no lim'rick, as yet,
But I've little regret:
Truth be told, it's no skin off my back.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Sue makes goo-goo eyes, hoping to win
The attention — love, maybe — of Glyn:
Flirty eyes, big and round —
She begins to make ground,
Little knowing the man is Glyn's twin.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
A good brand name, that's how it began.
To genericize? Never the plan.
It's a type product now,
But how could we allow
It to happen? Too late for a ban.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I petitioned the goddess Athena
To send me a live amphisbaena.
She replied from her stoa:
"Here's a nice rosy boa—
From Baja, and genus Charina."

limerick_list.author: Gravely
limerick_list.text:
I've no time for your scruples, your brooding. 
With our bling, and the chic we're exuding,
Let's go dance at our club,
Where our shoulders won't rub
With those pitiful shlubs we're excluding.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
While a date with Diane is a treat,
Her outlook is far from upbeat,
For Diane's anorexic
And also dyslexic,
Which means that she seldom will tea.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
In the doorway he'd lean on his broom,
His bay window occluding the room.
That commodious gut,
Like a belt-girdled hut,
Blocked the sunlight—the torso of doom.

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
I need surgery soon on my bladder.
Its condition could hardly be sadder,
And the cause of my groans?
I have ten bladder stones
(If my doctor's an accurate adder).

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
So you splash some and whimper a tad,
And it's curdled to boot, so you're sad;
Though it's thick, a bit lumpy
And sour—come on, Grumpy—
Don't cry over spilled milk gone bad!

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
Certain members, it seems, need reminding:
We don't allow effing and blinding.
We all took the oath:
Filthy language is loath;
And a gentleman's word should be binding.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
When the rains came, we sloshed and canoed.
Then our sewers backed up — we were screwed:
Feces flowed in the streets;
Sludge and muck messed our sheets.
Our sweet brook turned from babbling to rude.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Ahmadinejad asks for a day
Touring Frisco, our town by the bay.
If we schedule it right,
He'll be spending the night
At the Castro Street YMCA.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
The comb-jellies live in the sea
And in waters more brackish (q.v.).
They make up the corps o'
The group Ctenophora,
With ciliate "combs" swimming free.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"I am bumfuzzled, mixed up, confused."
"Tell me, what is that word you just used?"
"An expression, I guess,
From the southern U.S.,
That will peeve you yet leave you amused."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Cinderella, rewritten for rubes,
Rated "R", will go straight down the tubes.
You can blame Warner Brothers
For the Fairy Godmother's
Bare bibbidi-bobbidi-boobs.

limerick_list.author: John Ramos
limerick_list.text:
Exodontic procedures aren't risky.
I only need pliers and whiskey.
Here, son—take a drink.
Now say ahhh and don't blink.
Your tooth's pulled! (But your mom seems tsk-tsky.)

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
We old hippies (our parents' despair)
Like to think that our era was rare.
Our trousers' flared bagginess
Was matched by the shagginess
Of beards and moustaches and hair.

limerick_list.author: Dan A. Van Antwerp
limerick_list.text:
If your skin has a patch of red yeast
And you think that you look like a beast
Don't you wrinkle your brow;
Take some action right now.
Acrisorcin will see it decreased.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"That ain't fruit salad," Sar'n't Mosby blares,
"Those are ribbons and honors he wears.
That's his blood on his chest,
And y'all should be impressed!"
There was more, but the rest was all swears.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
I asked a physician named Dabney
If he'd shed some more light on my scabbed knee,
But he warned "If I do,
You will both look more blue,
Thanks to William de Wiveleslie Abney."

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
When defining adpressed I'm hard-pressed:
Said of foliage, may I suggest
That you think "leaves of heather
When snuggled together" —
That's the same as appressed. Who'da guessed?

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
The actor had added this note
On a glossy—for one fan he wrote,
"Your silence was golden,
For which I'm beholden.
Much obliged," (signed) "B. Holden" (end quote).

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Our aunt of a hundred and one
Banned our antics before they'd begun.
She dismissed any chat—
Anti-this, anti-that,
Anti-bliss, anti-brat, anti-fun!

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
It's real reason to sing, if I felt
That I could, with this hand I've been dealt.
Now's the time for some blues,
That might help pay my dues,
Make the lump in my heart start to melt.

limerick_list.author: Dr Bob Turvey
limerick_list.text:
Young people by acne are cursed,
With pretty ones often hit worst.
It's the pitting of skin
Due to hormones within,
And ruddy, great pimples that burst.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
For King Hamlet (not Lear or Macbeth),
Poisoned cochlea cost him his breath.
His brother, quite cheerful,
Turned spoonful to earful —
1 scant cochleare of death.

limerick_list.author: Rudi
limerick_list.text:
I hope you don't think me fanatical—
Though strict, I am not autocratical—
But I must apprise you
That you must revise "You
Is bad." "Is" is not, there, grammatical.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
I've
been
programming
spreadsheets
for
weeks,
With
default
data
entry
techniques.
Since
their
scheme,
in
the
norm,
Is
columnar
in
form,
I
have
lim'ricks
requiring
some
tweaks.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
As I walked up the stairs to the loge,
I chanced upon Aldo, the doge,
Who liked paintings.  I knew
That his most-favored hue
Was that strong, reddish yellow — gamboge.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It's so rampant it may overwhelm
Every shade tree that graces our realm.
It's a fungal disease
That is spread with great ease
And brings towns to their knees—the Dutch elm.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Pope Benedict (you know, the German)
Might relax, after giving a sermon,
In his personal space
With camauro in place.
That's a cap of red velvet and ermine.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
"Fatalities! Hundreds are killed
In the accident." Journalists, skilled
In disaster reporting,
Ask questions, while sporting
Sad faces, so pages are filled.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
So long to this bachelor's strife,
And aloha, my Mauian wife!
I'll be whiling the hours
With garlands of flowers,
Enjoying the leis of my life.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I am seeking a word or expression
To denote someone's loss of possession.
Divestment will serve,
As I haven't the nerve
For divestiture—that's my confession.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
What's this beautiful insect I see
Resting here, on my favorite tree?
It has wings red and black
And its larvae will snack
On some ragwort, their safe guarantee!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Express warranties (ones that are stated)
Guarantee that your purchase is rated
To perform as agreed.
That's just what you may need
If they lied and it sucks and you hate it.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
In black churches, when ministers preach,
The laity answers their speech.
Exaltation rewards
Their amens! and yes, Lords!
As their call-and-response sustains each.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
That a bird in the hand is worth two
In the bush is so patently true.
"A-B-I-T-H-I-"
And then "W-T-I-
T-B," if you're texting, will do.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
This notion can bring you to tears:
If you're talking and nobody hears.
If this happens to you,
Go to England (please do).
Find Prince Charles; he can help — he's all ears.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"About Vassar girls, I have surmised,"
Dorothy Parker, I've heard, once advised
As a joke, to a friend,
"Were they laid end to end,
I would not be the least bit surprised."

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
Michele Bachmann kicks up quite a fuss
While crusading, for votes, on her bus.
Though we might think her spacey —
(Where's Concord? Who's Gacy?),
Her fans say, "She's just one of us!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
At a sleazy cafe known as Abbott's,
Drinking greyhounds is one of my habits.
Made with grapefruit juice, gin,
Over ice—with a grin,
I'm soon chasing mechanical rabbits.

limerick_list.author: Nitelaf
limerick_list.text:
Mr. Whiskers was always demonic,
Running circles at speeds supersonic.
But he's now taken ill,
Sitting slack-jawed and still...
So the vet gave our poor cat a tonic.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Do you say Michiganian?"  "No.
I prefer Michigander.  Although
Lincoln used it to diss
Our state's governor, this
Is the term by which most of us go."

limerick_list.author: Aliza
limerick_list.text:
Pity the Barbary ape,
Just a monkey sans tail to its shape.
At home in Morocco
It's blown by scirocco;
From Gibraltar it cannot escape.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
I haven't got quite enough time
To write an original rhyme.
I need to make haste,
So I'll copy-and-paste!
He stood up and spat on the ceiling.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
There are body blows thrown in the ring—
They're permitted when pugilists swing.
But a punch that is felt
Much below a man's belt
Is taboo for the pain it can bring.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
It was clear, in the physics class, that
Little particles rained where I sat.
In those cloud chamber jars?
